On Christmas eve at La Fouche Lafauche , where the Division Surgeon's office was located, Major David S. Fairchild was made a Lieutenant-Colonel.

On the day before Christmas a detachment of twenty men left at Chalaines by Colorado to care for patients who could not be moved, rejoined their company. On Christmas eve Eve , a small consignment of mail and packages was received, bringing a taste of Christmas joy to the hearts of these men who were spending their first winter in France. Christmas dinner included turkey, with as many of the of the trimmings as could be obtained. The troops showed their spirit by decorating their barracks with holly and mistlletoe gathered from the nearby hills. For the first time since their arrival in France the men were permitted to send cablegrams to the folks, therby thereby leaving a few words of cheer in their vacant places by the old home fireplace.

Thus, despite the many unpleasant little initiations to bizarre tasks in the constant rains of Sunny France, despite the irksome ragging of the officious bosses, forgetting cheerless billets, and other hardship, the personnel of the 117th Sanitary Train passed a pleasant Christmas. They had become soldiers.

div.head: Through England
Chapter V
div.p: When the U. S. S. President Grant docked at Hoboken. N. J., about 3 o'clock in the afternoon of October 27, 1917, all troops were unloaded at once. Tennessee was sent to Fort Totten, N. Y., and ambulance section headquarters, New Jersey and Nebraska, to Fort Jay, Governor's Island, N. Y. Details were left at the dock by each organization to unload baggage and return the following day.

As usual during a move, the rain came down in torrents and everyone was drenched to the skin. but the boys made the best of it and relieved their feelings by singing the then popular song, Where Do We Go From Here. As to this they had not long to wonder, however, for on October 31, ambulance section headquarters, New Jersey and Nebraska, loaded on a ferry which took them to Weehauken, N. J., where they entrained for Dumont. They arrived late the same afternoon and marched to Camp Merritt, N. J. Tennessee remained at Fort Totten under quarantine during the entire time until again embarking for France.

Nearly everyone in the organizations stationed at Camp Merritt, received passes to visit New York City, and the men from New Jersey visited their homes. It was during the stay here that Captain Wilson, director of the ambulance section, was commissioned major.

On November 12, Private Jacques D. Wimpheimer Wimpfheimer was sent to the hospital in Englewood, New Jersey. A few days later he was removed to a hospital in Hoboken and on January 23, 1918, he died of pneumonia. He was the son of the Jersey Company's financial support and guardian, Charles A. Wimpheimer Wimpfheimer , prominent New York merchant.

On the morning of November 14, 1917, the four organizations received orders to embark a second time for France. This was accomplished the same morning. Ambulance section headquarters, New Jersey and Tennessee, embarked on the R. M. S. Aurania at pier 56, New York City, and Nebraska embarked on the White Star liner Celtic at pier 60, New York City. Both ships put out to sea at about 3:30 the same afternoon.

Life on board these English ships was more pleasant than it had been on the Grant. The men had better living quarters and were not so crowded. There were canteens aboard these
34 Iodine and Gasoline ships, where tobacco and cigarettes, cakes and fruit could be purchased at reasonable rates.

The Aurania was a better ship for comfort but the kitchen was English and it is needless to say that Chaze and Tay, twice a day was the diet during the voyage. The voyagers touched at Halifax, Nova Scotia, November 16, at 4 o'clock P. M. While here an opportunity was given all men to write home, the letters being gathered, censored and sent ashore. After waiting there forty-eight hours they joined the other ships of the convoy, nine in all, and put out to sea. A British cruiser in the harbor paid the Americans a tribute by allowing her band to play the Star Spangled Banner and the crew stood at attention as the convoy steamed past.

In spite of the bad weather the different organizations proceeded through a regular schedule of physical exercises and lifeboat drill. The gunners on the Celtic had target practice from time to time. The concerts which were rendered by the 168th Infantry band on the Aurania, the first few days of the trip, had to be discontinued on entering the war zone.

Due to the efforts of two Canadian Y. M. C. A. secretaries, who were crossing, to join their troops at the front, several first class entertainments were produced during the voyage. Among the best was a minstrel show given by a few of the boys from New Jersey and a benefit performance for the Orphans of British Seamen, in which members of the company took part.
The English sailors could not understand many traits of American soldiers, above all, how they could play poker and joke with such care-free actions when danger was all around.

When on November 25, the men were ordered to sleep with their clothes and life belts on, it was easy to guess that the convoy had reached the danger zone. November 28 proved to be the most exciting day of the journey, when something very similar to a periscope made its appearance a short distance away and passed within a hundred yards of the Aurania. The Sharpshooters who had been posted at different points on the ship some time before, opened fire with rifles. The Celtic immediately spun around, so as to present as small a target as possible, opening fire with her stern guns. Two destroyers were immediately on the scene firing perhaps a dozen shots in rapid succession. The alleged periscope disappeared, and the fleet changed its course, putting into Belfast harbor about dark. While the troop ships lay in the harbor, the accompanying destroyers scoured the Irish coast for submarines and mines.

Morning brought the rumor of a naval engagement and a
35Through England British ship was towed in with her stack shot away and her rigging badly damaged. . .

It was just a coincidence that Private James Brownlee of the New Jersey company could stand on deck at this point and see the chimney of his mother's home in Belfast, which he had left as a boy, ten years before. But being in the army and shore leaves not being granted, he was near and yet far. Taking a furlough from his post on the Rhine fifteen months later, Brownlee was at last permitted to visit his mother.

The fleet lay in the harbor on Thanksgiving day, while the stomachs of the men were being insulted with Australian rabbit, refrigerated for an uncertain number of years and finally cooked with the hair on. The Aurania had been transporting Canadian troops to France for three years. Maybe the management did not remember that the American Thanksgiving was a feast day, and that to starve Americans on that festive occasion was injury to the extreme.

Leaving two freighters, one of which was disabled, the remaining seven ships left the harbor of Belfast at 2:30 o'clock on the afternoon of Thanksgiving, convoyed by nine destroyers. They proceeded at top speed under cover of darkneas to Liverpool, England, casting anchor at one o'clock A. M., December 1, 1917. It was indeed a happy crowd who marched down the gang plank and immediately to the depot of the London and Northwestern railway.

It was on this march that Private Joseph Keenan of the Tennessee company passed within a few blocks of his childhood home but was unable to leave his company to visit his people. Keenan was also granted a pass to England while Quartered quartered on the Rhine more than a year later.

After waiting nine hours in the cold, Major Wilson, in charge of the troops, was approached by an English Lieutenant, in charge of railway transportation, who announced the coming of the troop train by saying The King has granted you permission to ride. Accordingly all four organizations were loaded into third class coaches and pulled out for Camp Wendledown, Winchester. The train stopped at Birmingham for an hour, where tea and coffee were served. The men were granted permission to leave the train and stretch their legs during, the pause. It was here that a rather distinguished looking Englishman past middle age, accompanied by a woman, presumably his wife, gazed curiously at a group of American soldiers and finally asked:
No province sir, answered the boys. We are Americans.
Indeed, said the woman, and what part of the United States is your home?
We are Tennesseeans Tennesseans , from Memphis to be exact, was the answer.
Ah, how singular, she exclaimed. I have been in Memphis but I never knew that Tennessee had declared war.
The two departed, leaving a quartet of stunned, gaping national guardsmen, wondering whether the fine lady had been on the banks of the Mississippi or the Nile when she was in Memphis.

From Birmingham the troops were carried into Winchester arriving there about one o'clock the following morning. The weather was extremely cold and compared favorably with the Americans' reception. They were in no too good a humor for a long, cold, uphill hike to the rest camp. After a delay of an hour or so they were assigned billets which were constructed of corrugated iron sheeting, with varnished cloth windows and each man was given three pieces of plank for a bed.

In the morning they awoke to find themselves in the center of a large English training camp. It was their first experience with the Adrian barracks, equipped with one small stove, and allowed one whole bucket of coal every twenty-four hours.

During the stay, part of the time was spent in sightseeing hikes in and about the city of Winchester. Some of the most interesting sights were King Arthur's Round Table, College and Church of Winchester, the college being the oldest in England. Most of the spare time in camp was spent in Hooverizing on English rations of bread, cheese and tea. The menu was changed only once, when sardines were substituted for cheese.

On December 11, ambulance section headquarters, New Jersey, Tennessee and Nebraska, left Camp Wendledown for Southhampton Southampton and crossed the English Channel cooped up on the Marguerite. Just before sailing, the king again opened up his heart and issued one tin of bully-beef per man. Some of the braver hearts tackled this beef and proceeded to wrestle with it all during the voyage, but the beef won in nearly every case and the fish profited thereby. No one doubted that the officer who had charge of loading the good ship "Marguerite" had had previous experience as a packer in a sardine factory.

Arriving at La Havre, rest camp No.2, the different organizations were assigned to so-called billets. They resembled the old western lean-to of the days of Daniel Boone, with one side wide open to the elements.

Headquarters detachment and the three companies entrained for La Fouche Lafauche on December 13, in third class coaches, minus
37Through England doors and windows. Each five men received one can of monkey meat and five packages of bard tack for two days' rations. However, they did not have to depend on this entirely, as black coffee was served once during the two days days' trip.

The hungry, sleepy, and half frozen Americans arrived at La Fouche at about nine o'clock on the morning of December 15, detrained and hiked a mile and a half to the town. It had a popu1ation of about half a hundred souls. At last the Americans had found one of those long looked for French Chateaux.

But how different was it in reality, from what had been expected! In the assignment of billets, Nebraska drew compartments in the crumbling outer wall of a demolished castle, built in the fifteenth century, and the other companies were housed in the town proper, in shacks more or less dilapidated, entirely lacking in conveniences and even without heat. On December 22, these dismal quarters were honored by a visit from the new division commander, Major General Charles T. Menoher, who had succeeded General Mann.

Had it not been for the reserve rations the men carried in their packs, these two weeks would have been eatless days indeed. The greater part of the division which had come to France a month earlier, was now in the middle of a long overland hike, and was far removed from the American base of supplies. Rations were scarce and the arrival of 350 more men only made matters worse. The only meal of the two weeks was on Christmas day, when all precedents were violated and an ambulance was dispatched to scour the countryside and spend the mess funds for anything the French populace would part with. A mixture of canned meat and onions with hard tack and coffee twice a day was the unaltering menu.

No word but desolate, could have rightly described La Fouche Lafauche . It was perched on the side of a big hill a kilometer from the main road. In sight were many other villages of the same size, all muddy, dirty and deserted looking. Fuel was at a premium. The Jersey men were assessed two francs each the next pay day to remunerate their landlord for his fagots that they had appropriated in lieu of fuel.

Division headquarters offices were in La Fouche Lafauche , set up in a group of Adrian barracks on the edge of town. The other five companies of the train were five kilometers away at a small town called St. Blin.

Shortly after his arrival, Major Wilson took command of the ambulance section again and the field hospitals admitted the prodigal Nebraskans into their midst, and the train was again in working order.

div.head: The Hike
Chapter VI
div.p: Lest the truths set forth in this chapter appear to be a veiled criticism of necessary and rightful authority; or lest they assume the guise of a complaint against the ordinary hardships of a soldier's outdoor life, it is well to recall the time when the incidents took place. The year 1917 was still alive. The American Expeditionary Force in France was still an experiment. The old methods of handling an army, in force since the Spanish-American war, had not been altered to fit the conditions of the greatest war the world had ever seen.

It is not worth while worthwhile to dwell upon the success of this A. E. F. experiment. Such victories are not won in seclusion. Everybody knows that America built up the most wonderful and efficient service of supply that ever existed, and kept alive an army on the other side of the globe from her resources. But that was an accomplishment of the next year. Until Christmas, 1917, much of America's shipping facilities was still in the forest and mine. The wonderful service of supply existed only on paper. The American fighting force had everything to learn about modern warfare and the French and British were still holding the line.

The people in America were contributing lavishly and blindly of their money, only wondering what the outcome of this experiment would be. The officers and men of the A. E. F. in the meantime waited in their muddy French villages, also wondering what the outcome would be, knowing that they were the material upon which the experiment would be tried. And among them was the 117th Sanitary Train in La Fouche Lafauche and St. Blin. In justice to the men, it must be said that their dread of the coming march was not born of any silk-stockinged mollycoddleism. It was evident that their present abodes were not permanent, for deep as were the mysteries of army movements at that time, the men knew that their ultimate destination lay much farther ahead, three or four days' walking distance.

If a great many of the men grumbled at the prospect of walking through country netted by railroads, it was because they did not realize that the battle then raging in Italy was taxing the French railroads to their very limit. The two thousand cars necessary to transport the division by rail could ill be spared from the Allies' lines of supply, to say nothing of fuel and engines. The
39 The Hike men knew that things were not as they should be, but they did not stop to consider that America's war plans, like all new things, were subject to many mistakes and subsequent corrections; and that they, who had come early, must accept the consequences of the inevitable mistakes.

For a few days previous to Christmas, rumors had been floating around, to the effect that the train was to make a three-day hike. Consequently, at first call for reveille everyone awakened expectantly on the morning of December 27, just before dawn. It had been very cold, and during the night five or six inches of snow had fallen. By the time everyone was dressed, light of day had driven away the inky darkness of the night before. And what a sight was presented to the eyes! The earth, building and every tree, were enveloped in a great white blanket, such as only nature can provide. The air was full of large feathery flakes, that were slowly descending to thicken that blanket.

Had the men been at home, with sleds and sleighs, this day would have been a delightful one, but that little dream had to be banished. The hard fact that this was France and they were as yet not acclimated, and a long hike was to begin in an hour, put an entirely different interpretation on the picture without.

The Division Surgeon's office force had fared luckier that the train's personnel, for it had departed by truck for Rolampont the day before, making the complete trip in a day. Frost-bitten ears and fingers made the trip miserable enough for them, but when compared with the pedestrian's experience, the trucks were palace cars.

Ambulance section headquarters and fie1d hospital headquarters hiked with the train, enduring the hardships of those memorable days as best they could. Every company was short of transportation and as a result, the few combat wagons available were loaded to the breaking point, in some cases to be drawn by two smooth-shod mules over roads that would have rendered an empty wagon a burden.

A few moments after 8 o'clock, ambulance section headquarters, Jersey, Tennessee, and Nebraska, left the village of La Fouche whither they knew not, and cared less, so long as they got there. Hiking was anything but easy, plodding through eight inches of snow, under a sixty-pound pack. Many of the men's shoes were completely unserviceable and they made their first letters from home serve a dual purpose, inserting them in their shoes to keep their feet off the ground.

There were a great many trucks on the road, all heavily loaded, going in the same direction the troops were marching.
40 The Hike These trucks had to have the middle of the road. If they veered too much to one side they were sure to skid into the ditch, which meant a delay of perchance a whole day. This forced the men to keep well over to the right of the road where the ground was slanting and the footing uncertain.

Anybody who ever traveled over a French highway knows what the right hand side looks like. Besides the trees which stand thirty feet apart, the government keeps small piles of crushed rock, stacked between every two trees, for the purpose of repairing the road. So it was around these trees and over these rock piles on the slanting roadside that part of the column had to plod.

Fifty minutes of hiking and ten minutes of rest per hour was the plan followed. About 10 o'clock A. M. the column reached St. Blin and the complete train was once more together for the first time since leaving Camp Mills. The last hike they had taken together was on Long Island, without packs, over the best roads in the world, on an ideal autumn morning. This reminded them of that hike, because it was so different. In a few minutes the five additional companies had taken their places in line. These five organizations had been in France six weeks, and had made one long hike and had done much outdoor labor. In that respect they were better prepared for the coming ordeal than the group from La Fouche Lafauche .

Someone was setting the pace with a motorcycle, who evidently had no idea what walking in a new-fal1en snow was like. This gait was especially hard on the three companies who had already been hiking for two hours. Within a short time, Oklahoma's four accompanying Flivvers came into demand, as the snow combined with the huge pack, containing most everything a soldier needs but the kitchen stove, had commenced to tell on the embryo campaigners. A few fell out before noon, but as the day grew older, the number of exhausted increased, and the ambulances had all they could do to bring in the stragglers.

A halt was called at noon on the outskirts of Remicourt Rimaucourt for lunch. The train marched into an open field by the roadside and there, feet buried in the snow, unslung packs and waited for the wagon train to catch up. When it came, coffee would be made and served. The thermometer stood very close to zero. Every man's clothing was moist from perspiration and it took a very few minutes to chill the men to the bone. Here the foundation was laid for many cases of pneumonia that developed in the next few days for an hour had passed before each man had received his one-third cup of half-boiled black unsweetened coffee.

Oh! how they wished they had some of the honey they had bought a few days before. A Frenchman near St. Blin discovered while the troops were there that a bee-hive had been robbed. The sanitary train had not seen any of the honey, but they were camped near and were taxed to cover the loss anyway. The lost honey was less than a quart. The bill was six hundred francs, and it was paid. And now, with all their hearts, the men wished they had stolen hives and all. But the bitter coffee was gulped down and the men waited impatiently for the tramp to start again, for they could at least keep warm marching.

In the afternoon, the train passed through Remicourt Rimaucourt . The very elements of nature had conspired against them. One hill after another in rapid succession, with hardly ever a descent, combined with a blinding snowstorm, almost a blizzard in form, made progress not only painful but next to impossible. Many of the unseasoned lads fell exhausted into the snow trusting that an ambulance would come along before nightfall.

About dusk the column reached the little lane leading to the village of Echot Ecot , about one kilometer from the main road. Ambulance section headquarters, Jersey, Tennessee and Nebraska, were assigned to this town for the night. A feeble tubercular cheer arose from the men of these four organizations, for at last the end of the trail was in sight where a place to rest might be had. The billets were good, being in an old chateau and in houses near it. Some of the rooms even had fireplaces and fires were built, though officially there were no fires, for officially there was no fuel. The stack of wood in the court yard belonged to the Frenchman who owned the chateau. Some of the men spent part of their rightful sleeping while trying to negotiate legitimately for the wood, but most of the men pursued a less exemplary, but more practical course, and had a fire. The wife of the old Frenchman took pity on the wet, shivering soldiers and told them to be careful and get the wood between five and six o'clock while her husband was in the back hall milking the goats, or he would make trouble for them. After the fires were roaring and the men were having the novel experience of thawing, they threw their packs on the floor and fell on top of them, too tired to get up two hours later for supper. Soon all minds were dead to the world sleeping only as exhausted men can, dreamless and quiet even upon a mattress of oak.

Field hospital headquarters and the five companies who started last, pushed on to Forcey the same evening, where they were to spend the night. Due to an oversight, probably, it was more than an hour after they arrived in town before billets could
42 Iodine and Gasoline be obtained and the men assigned places, in spite of the fact that a billeting officer had been sent ahead to prepare for the emergency. At the end of this hour of waiting in the street, the men were rewarded with well-ventilated billets. For there were plenty of holes in the roof and some in the walls as well. These barns were as cold within as the streets without, except that there was a place to take refuge from the winds.

Morning brought unique problems. Under the hay and blankets the all-essential feet had swollen out of proportion, while on the floor every shoe had frozen stiff. Some of the men lighted candles inside of their shoes, others stuffed them full of hay and set the hay on fire. The barn was full of smoke and resourcefulness, and by 9:30 o'clock, when the companies from Echot Ecot arrived, they were ready to go, and go they did, in the same direction, southward and upward, slipping and limping.

The second day tested the soldier's mettle. After the column had left Forcey an hour behind, snow once more started falling. Again it was driven by a gale that assumed the appearance of a blizzard. The thermometer started falling and continued to drop all day. It was impossible to see a hundred yards ahead. Stragglers increased in number. Men who fell out lay prone in the snow, or sat propped up against trees by the roadside, waiting for the overworked ambulances.

At noon a halt was called for lunch. The meal consisted of cold corned beef sandwiches. The first five minutes saw the sandwiches disappear, but the prescribed hour rest had to be observed, and the airing that went along with it had to be endured. The time was spent in trying prescriptions for keeping warm without a fire. Finally the march was resumed and the men were glad to be on their way once more.
The afternoon was a repetition of the morning.

The worst of all calamities befell the Nebraskans. Their kitchen was in the ditch, incidentally, the accident occurred just before noon. The hill had been hard for those on foot, but for the donkeys and wagon, it had been too much. The mules tried and failed. The driver coaxed the team in ways known only to his profession and failed. Then men were called to help, and they were successful in pushing the load half way up the grade where it slipped and ran backward, off the road and upside down. Then the air grew warm, for if Sherman had been in France instead of Georgia he would have used more than three words to describe war.

The whole wagon train was stuck. This meant to summon help from the Allies, or let the men go to bed without sup-
43The Hike per. So a Frenchman was called into conference. Much confab followed. After wild gestures with head and limbs and a discreet use of a few familiar words, the Frog understood. He thereupon spat out a string of oui', and departed, returning presently with a yoke of oxen. One at a time the wagons were towed to the top of the hill, and the wagon train struggled on. The Frenchman accepted two cane of corned bill for his trouble and seemed delighted with the remuneration. If this had been the last hill, all would have been well, but there were others. Twice that afternoon it was necessary to remove half the load from each wagon at the foot of the hill, and pull the rest to the top, sending the wagons back to get the rest of the load.

At 3 o'clock in the afternoon, Mandres
greated greeted the eyes of the marching troops. Jersey, Tennessee, Nebraska and ambulance section headquarters were to spend their second night there and they halted for the day. It was a small town of hospitable people and airy billets, and the temperature had fallen ten degrees below zero, Fahrenheit.

Again the other five companies struggled a little farther on, halting at Nogent-en-Bassigny where they were quartered. It was their turn for better quarters, and they got them. The billets were warm and the cafes in town had hot meals for sale. Needless to say, they did a rushing business. The men profited by the experience of the night before and took their shoes to bed with them, where the heat of their bodies prevented them from freezing. And the next morning the thermometer was hovering around fifteen below zero.

The men in Mandres did not take off any of their clothes. They were ready to start at the first bugle note, when they threw themselves free from their blankets and 8 o'clock found the column on the road again. Every man was traveling on his nerve next day. A number of the hikers had to be left behind at Mandres to be called for by ambulances later. The rest of the train fell in line at Nogent about 9:30. The column was shorter by this time but the train was on the home stretch at last. Those hardy ones remaining were rewarded by a few rays of sun. Even the early morning was bright and before 10 o'clock the weather started to moderate. Hiking was comfortable, even though every man was tired and footsore.
At noon on December 29, the commander of the column called a halt in the village of Rolampont, where 42nd Division Headquarters was already situated. The ambulance men had reached their destination.

A reason was never stated for making the Christmas hike.
44 Iodine and Gasoline Sometimes it was called a practice march. Sometimes it was called a strategic retreat from the Toul sector where unusual activity was threatened. But neither was authenticated. To the men it was a campaign, and by no means the easiest one in the war. Whatever the purpose might have been, that purpose was thwarted by the unexpected blizzard. If it was planned as a hardening and strengthening maneuver for the men, the plan was frustrated, for the worst blizzard of an unusually severe winter on the Langres plateau overtook them before the journey was half made.

The most unhappy recollections of the service overseas are draped about the happenings during this early campaign against cold and unfitness for hardships. The flies and stench and sleepless nights of the month at Chateau-Thierry ; the muck and bottomless roads and ceaseless rain and hostile bombers of the Argonne ; neither was hard enough to make the men complain, because at that time they understood the necessity of it all. And in those later months they understood that this first battle with King Winter was only the reward of a volunteer, who came early to be sacrificed to the American cause while it was still in the experimental stage. The discontent at the time was due to the apparent non-necessity of it all, or perhaps memories of comrades who need not have died.

Refreshed by an eighteen hour rest, the four hospital companies with their headquarters detachment renewed the march from Rolampont on the morning of December 30. The day was clear and fair and had advantages over some of the foregoing ones, but it was a painful hike. They passed on over the heights of Langres and down on the last lap of the journey to Longeau Longeaux , arriving there at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and being assigned to quarters.
They marched into regulation French barracks, with floors of soft mud and a small sheet-iron stove at one end. They made themselves comfortable there and waited for the coming of Happy New Year.
